stream_context.summary: Kaze debugged a crash in the overworld caused by a coin formation. He then began designing and building a new retro level for Course 13, deciding on a 3D rail-shooter concept based on the plane stage from Super Mario Land 1 and starting work on the level geometry and player model.

development_findings.summary: The project has a strict design rule that all 'retro' themed levels must be based on games released before Super Mario 64.
development_findings.quote: Why not doing anything that released after Mario 64, maybe? That's the rule. We want it to fit in the time.

development_findings.summary: The Super Mario Land 1 level will be a 60 FPS rail-shooter with a fixed camera, where the player moves on a 2D plane within the camera's view.
development_findings.quote: It will be forced perspective. The camera will be permanently stuck like this. Then you're allowed to move in screen space, but you're not allowed to move the location of the camera.

development_findings.summary: Kaze debugged a persistent crash by methodically removing objects, eventually isolating the cause to a specific coin formation actor in the overworld.
development_findings.quote: Aha! This was the cause for the crash.

development_findings.summary: Kaze decided to add fog to the Super Mario Land 1 level to manage draw distance, prioritizing visual coherence over maintaining a perfectly clean retro aesthetic.
development_findings.quote: if we have no fog and you can see the entire level until the entire end here, it's gonna look like ass. We need fog.

development_findings.summary: A significant, project-wide technical change was made by swapping the rendering order of two draw layers, requiring a tedious manual update across all level files.
development_findings.quote: I'm swapping layer 5 and layer 6, because I swapped them on my repo. These have to be swapped. In every level.

development_findings.summary: Kaze began the asset creation process for the SML1 level by creating a low-poly 3D model of Mario's plane, based on the original 16x16 game sprite.
The project is nearing completion of its main courses, with the Super Mario Land 1 'Space Arcade' level and a 'Papercraft' level being the final two in development.
development_findings.quote: The Space Arcade and the Papercraft level are the last two.

context_findings.summary: Kaze plans to increase his streaming and work schedule to earn more money in preparation for the birth of his child, stating he is more efficient while streaming.
context_findings.quote: I got three whole months of it long for having a child. But also, I need to work more because I want to make more money. So that's why I'm gonna just stream like basically every day now. Because I'm very efficient working on stream.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's parents are visiting for ten days, providing a brief look into his personal life and family relationship.
context_findings.quote: My parents are visiting us in Germany right now, and it's quite a bit of work... they brought like 15 Yoshis. I have so many Yoshi plushies now.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's personal nostalgia is a significant factor in creative decisions, such as insisting on a Super Mario Land 1 level over other suggestions.
context_findings.quote: I haven't played Land 2 as a child. So for me, Land 1 is like the only one that I will have some nostalgia for.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes the original Super Mario 64's performance issues were due to inefficient programming and that he could have fixed them to achieve 30 FPS and add Luigi with minimal effort.
context_findings.quote: The first thing I do is fix the graph render code. Make it all fit into one block of cache. And now the entire game runs at 30 FPS. And we can add Luigi to the game. And it's going to be two days of work.

context_findings.summary: Kaze exclusively develops and tests on a specific version of Project64, acknowledging its flaws but stating that learning to work around the bugs of one emulator is more efficient than supporting multiple.
context_findings.quote: The thing is, every emulator is broken as fuck. It's just that I've been using this emulator because this one is the easiest one to use. And I work around the bugs in this emulator.

biobak.summary: Biobak participated in brainstorming for the retro level, suggesting Wario Land (Super Mario Land 3) as a possibility before Kaze settled on Super Mario Land 1.
biobak.quote: Super Mario Land 3, Mario Land type Retro Level. Didn't that come out after Mario 64? Oh, it was 1994. I guess that works too. But I really want Mario Land 1.

zeina.summary: Kaze briefly and affectionately refers to Zeina during a meme reveal on his computer.

key_stories.title: Debugging the Coin Formation Crash
key_stories.summary: When faced with a persistent and mysterious crash, Kaze demonstrated his debugging methodology. He systematically ruled out potential causes, eventually isolating the problem to a single coin formation actor, showcasing his problem-solving approach.
key_stories.challenge: The game was consistently crashing when loading the overworld, and the source of the crash was unknown.
key_stories.process: Kaze first hypothesized the crash was due to too many collision triangles, but removing them didn't solve it. He then correctly deduced it was an actor. By systematically removing potential problem objects (coin formations) and re-testing, he used a process of elimination to isolate the single faulty object.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully identified a specific coin formation as the source of the crash, allowing him to fix the issue and continue development.
key_stories.key_quote: Aha! This was the cause for the crash.

key_stories.title: Designing the Super Mario Land 1 Retro Level
key_stories.summary: Kaze was determined to include a Super Mario Land 1 level despite its perceived simplicity. After rejecting concepts that felt like a step back, he pivoted to adapting the plane stage into a 3D rail-shooter, finding a creative solution that honored the source material while creating new gameplay.
key_stories.challenge: The team needed a compelling concept for a retro level based on Super Mario Land 1, a game Kaze was nostalgic for but which others felt might be less interesting than its sequel.
key_stories.process: Kaze was adamant about including SML1. He considered and rejected adapting the submarine levels, fearing it would require too much new sprite work and be uninteresting. After reviewing the game's levels, he identified the plane stage (4-3) as having the most potential for a unique 3D adaptation, brainstorming the fixed-camera shooter mechanic on stream.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze decided on a 3D rail-shooter concept based on the plane stage from SML1. This new direction was met with enthusiasm, and he immediately began creating the level's structure and core assets.
key_stories.key_quote: I don't want to make the same game, but worse... Okay, wait, this looks a hundred times better.
